entry.et: Middle English envie, from Anglo-French, from Latin invidia, from invidus envious, from invidēre to look askance at, envy, from in- + vidēre to see wit

def.dt: :painful or resentful awareness of an advantage enjoyed by another joined with a desire to possess the same advantage
:an object of envious notice or feeling his new car made him the envy of his friends
:to feel envy toward or on account of
:the supposed coveting of the penis by a young human female which is held in Freudian psychoanalytic theory to lead to feelings of inferiority and defensive or compensatory behavior
